ud4.4:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ud4.4:1.3: At that time Venerables Sāriputta and Moggallāna were staying near the pigeons’ alcove.
ud4.4:1.4: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting outdoors in the moonlight, his head freshly shaven, having entered a certain state of immersion.
ud4.4:2.1: Now at that time two native spirits who were friends were on their way from the north to the south on some business.
ud4.4:2.3: One of the spirits said to the other,
ud4.4:2.4: “I feel inspired, friend, to give this ascetic a blow on the head!”
ud4.4:2.7: That is an eminent ascetic, powerful and mighty!”
ud4.4:3.1: For a second time the first spirit said to the other,
ud4.4:3.2: “I feel inspired, friend, to give this ascetic a blow on the head!”
ud4.4:3.3: For a second time, the other spirit replied,
ud4.4:3.5: That is an eminent ascetic, powerful and mighty!”
ud4.4:3.6: For a third time the first spirit said to the other,
ud4.4:3.7: “I feel inspired, friend, to give this ascetic a blow on the head!”
ud4.4:3.8: For a third time, the other spirit replied,
ud4.4:3.10: That is an eminent ascetic, powerful and mighty!”
ud4.4:4.1: Ignoring his friend, the first spirit gave Sāriputta a blow on the head.
ud4.4:4.2: The blow was so strong it would have felled a bull elephant seven or seven and a half cubits tall, or split apart a great mountain peak.
ud4.4:4.3: But then the spirit, crying out, “I burn, I burn!” fell into the Great Hell right there.
ud4.4:5.1: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, Venerable Moggallāna saw that spirit giving a blow to Venerable Sāriputta.
